question.title: How to truncate final result in java (Recursion)
question.body:
I am working on this code that has this design

public static String combine(String first, String second, int n);

so this takes 2 strings and returns the 2 Strings for n times. Ex. the input ("Good", "Morning", 3) the output should be "Good Morning Good".

My implementation is using recursion where the base case is stating if n is less than or equal to 0 that it should return "". For any number greater than 0, it should concatenate the first + " " + second + " " + combine(first, second, n-1). Then this results in the output, "Good Morning Good Morning Good Morning", so now I am thinking of taking the length of the result and only taking the substring from 0 to half the length of the result string. However, when I try this, I get "Good Mornin" instead. I'm sort of stumped on how I can truncate it to "Good Morning Good".

Here is my code:

public static String combine(String first, String second, int n) {

        if(n <= 0) {
            return "";
        }
        else {
            String result = first + " " + second + " " + combine(first, second, n - 1);
            int d = result.length();
            
             
            return result.substring(0, d/2);    
            }   
    }

Thank you
